oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Doing the wash
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Laundry; Domestic life; Laundresses; Housework; Kettles; African Americans; Women domestics; Houses; Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An African American woman is pictured at the back of a multi-story dwelling stirring laundry that is heating over a fire in a black iron kettle. The house, with clothes drying on the porch rails, is visibile behind her. A dinner bell is mounted beside the front porch.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A mule-powered ferry boat at river landing
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mules; Kettles; Rocks; Waterfronts; Rivers; African Americans; Men; Boats; Dwellings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A waterfront view showing three African American men. One man sits at the edge of the river near a mule-powered ferry. The second man is on the ferry with two mules. The third man sits above the bank on a cliff. Rocks, driftwood and a large iron kettle populate the riverbank. Several building structures are pictured in the background above the riverbank.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The typical 19th century ferry boat was powered by horses or mules. The ferries were essential in transporting people and goods across the river in the days before bridges.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Two African-American women and baby on porch of river dwelling
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Domestic life; Porches; Families; Log cabins; African Americans; Bodies of water
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two African-American women are seated on the porch of a primitive log dwelling with a baby playing at their feet. A river appears in the background.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oxen and handler
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Cattle; Laborers; Carts & wagons; African Americans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: African-American man reins in two yoked oxen in a field as a group of women stand, sit in, and walk around a wagon. Structures appear in the background.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oxen were a major work animal in 19th century Tennessee and supplied much of the power associated with loading and unloading cargo-laden steamboats.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: River landing with steamboat ramp or gang plank
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Laborers; City & town life; Bodies of water
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: People gathered at a river landing. There is also a boom gangplank, horses, and mules in the image. In the background there appears town buildings.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oxen team hauling crossties at tieyard
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Logs; Lumber industry; Lumber; Ox teams; Cattle; Carts & wagons; Cutover lands; Clearing of land; Bodies of water
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A team of oxen yoked together stand beside wagons loaded with hand hewn crossties. The crossties were hewn by seasonal workers using a broadaxe and delivered to river landing tieyards for shipping by steamboat.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Railroad crossties were a major form of timber and part-time agricultural work well into the 20th century; the ties were collected and shipped at river landing tieyards such as the one depicted here.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Workers roll barrels in shadow of general store
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: General stores; Inclined planes; Laborers; Waterfronts; Barrels; City & town life; African Americans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Town along the river is featured with two African-American workers rolling barrels along a loading ramp. William A. Lueders General Merchandise Store, storage barn, and other buildings appear in the background. The William A. Lueders General Merchandise Store has a hanging Wittenberg P.O. sign.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The river town of Wittenberg was located in Perry County, Missouri.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Man standing at pilot's wheel on steamboat
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Steamboats; Men
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Man standing next to the pilot's wheel on a steamboat. Pictured are the bell pulls for the Engine Room Telegraph, pull rope for the whistle or roof bell, steering lever and pilot wheel, decorative rope over the front window, and a megaphone on the floor in front of the pilot.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Man holding chickens
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Birds; Chickens; Rivers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: African American male holding large chickens by their feet. An unidentified river is in the background.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "City of Savannah"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Steamboats; Stern wheelers; African Americans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "City of Savannah," a stern wheeler steamboat, plowing through the water belching smoke through the tall stacks. Some individuals are shown on the decks. One lifeboat is visible on one of the decks.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The "City of Savannah" was built at Jeffersonville, Indiana, in 1902 for the St. Louis & Tennessee River Packet Company. In 1912, it was lost on the Mississippi River above Cairo and sank on a snag at Elkins Lodge.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Man hauling bags in a steamboat
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Barrels; Bags; Steamboats; Laborers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: African-American man caries a heavy cloth bag of unidentified goods, possibly peanuts, on his back. Behind him another man carries the same. Rows of cloth bags and barrels of goods are pictured.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Peanuts were a common cargo carried on steamboats. "Roustabouts" was the name given to the men who handled freight on the commercial steamboats that plied Southern rivers after the Civil War. Many worked at the river landings where the boats made stops.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "City of Memphis" at river landing
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Steamboats; Bodies of water; Laborers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The "City of Memphis" is moored at the shore while cargo is loaded on board via a boom gangplank. Several well dressed men and women seem to be waiting to board. The tall stacks are belching black smoke in preparation for moving. Individuals are shown on all three decks.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The "City of Memphis" was built at Jeffersonville, Indiana, in 1898 for the St. Louis & Tennessee River Packet Company. She was placed in the St. Louis and Memphis trade in competition with the "Georgia Lee" and a rate war resulted. She then went to the Tennessee River trade until 1910 when bought by Captian Tom Horrissy of Vicksburg, Mississippi, and renamed "S.B. Duncan," in January 1900. When in the St. Louis-Memphis trade she sank while crossing from Rosa Lodge, Arkansas, to Gold Dust, Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Carnegie Public Library
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Libraries; Public libraries
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Substanial two-story brick building with domed cupola. Round windows complement the six-sided lower part of dome. Three narrow arched windows and large arched front door are symmetrically placed along facade. Four stone Ionic columns grace the facade and carved is "Carnegie Public Library". Snow covers the ground.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Men standing beneath a shelter at a well
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Men; African Americans; Shelters; Wells
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Group of five men standing beneath a shelter filling glass bottles with water from a well. Some of the men appear to be African Americans and there is a young boy in the background.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Women walking down the riverbank
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Women; Waterfronts; Steamboats; Rivers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A group of women are walking down the bank of a river. A steamboat can be seen docking at the river. The women are wearing long dresses and hats. The steamboat is the "City of Memphis."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This image provides a distant view of a mule-powered ferry boat next to the river landing. The ferry was attached to a line that ran shore to shore. The mule provided the power for the boat to travel from one side of the shore to the other.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hogs driven onto steamboat
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Swine; Corrals; Laborers; Agriculture
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A group of men are gathering up hogs and guiding them up a wooden chute onto a steamboat to send them off for slaughter. Most of the men pictured are African American.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: It was common to send hogs off to slaughter by water rather than by land. If they were driven over land, they would lose weight and therefore some of their value.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Passengers on deck
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Men; Women; Clothing & dress; Steamboats
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Six women and two men, probably passengers, are posing in front of smokestacks on the deck of a steamboat. The Texas deck can be seen at far right in the background. This steamboat is most likely the "City of Memphis."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Texas Deck, a long and narrow cabin for officers, was the top deck located under the pilot house. This type of deck was added to many steamboats at the same time Texas became part of the United States.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wagon with mules
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mules; Carts & wagons; Cotton
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A posed picture showing six individuals in hats (three men and three women) on and beside a wagon pulled by two mules. Two of the men are wearing riverboat captain's hats. In the background there appears to be bailed cotton with at least two individuals on top.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Young African-American girls
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; African Americans; Girls; Fences; Bonnets; Clothing & dress
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A group of five African-American girls are gathered together near a wooden fence and wooden house. Several of the girls are smiling. A white woman in a long dress can be seen in the background walking the other way.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Team of oxen
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Steamboats; Ox teams; Laborers; Rivers; Farming; Bodies of water
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A man with a hat stands next to a team of oxen. A river and a steamboat can be seen in the background. The man is standing near some wooden structures, one of which may be a barn. The name of the steamboat is the "City of Memphis."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oxen were the predominant work animal in the American South up to the late nineteenth century. Yoked oxen were well-suited for heavy loads - perfect for lifting heavy wagons up muddy river landings. Oxen were heavy-duty, strong, but slow animals. Prior to mules, oxen were often used in agricultural labor. The fact that these workers were still using oxen ca. 1900 is significant.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Roustabouts" on deck of steamboat
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Waterfronts; Labor supply; Men; Laborers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four African-American men relax on the deck of a riverboat. The man in front wears blue jeans, vest, coat, and boots. The man in back wears overalls and a plaid shirt. Visible in the background are stacked wooden boxes.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Roustabouts" was the name given to the men who handled freight on the commercial steamboats that plied Southern rivers after the Civil War. While these men are on board, many worked at the river landings where the boats made stops.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Watching the sternwheel steamboat pass
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Boys; Rivers; Children; Trees; Stern wheelers; Steamboats
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One African-American man and two boys, all wearing caps, perched on tree roots by a river. The sternwheel of a steamboat can be seen at left.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Roustabouts" was the name given to the men who handled freight on the commercial steamboats that plied Southern rivers after the Civil War. Many worked at the river landings where the boats made stops.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Man peeking out of outhouse
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Privies; Men; Ship captains
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mustachioed man wears captain's hat, glasses, and striped bowtie. He is visible from the chest and shoulders up and is standing inside what appears to be an outhouse or some sort of out building. The building is of crude construction, built with vertical boards and rectangular "window".
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Man sitting on Texas deck of "City of Memphis"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Steamboats; Men; Ship captains
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: White-bearded stout man wearing captain's hat and sitting in a chair on the Texas deck of the steamboat "City of Memphis". The Texas Deck, a long and narrow cabin for officers, was located on a raised section over the skylights of a steamboat. This type of deck was added to many steamboats at the same time Texas became part of the United States.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The "City of Memphis" was built at Jeffersonville, Indiana, in 1898 for the St. Louis & Tennessee River Packet Company. She was placed in the St. Louis and Memphis trade in competition with the "Georgia Lee" and a rate war resulted. She then went to the Tennessee River trade until 1910 when bought by Captian Tom Horrissy of Vicksburg, Mississippi, and renamed "S.B. Duncan." When in the St. Louis-Memphis trade she sank, January 1900, while crossing from Rosa Lodge, Arkansas, to Gold Dust, Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees, that may be necessary for the intended use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Flooded farm
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Floods; Bodies of water; Disasters
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Flooding river rising to homes, barns, and other outbuildings, probably on Mississippi or Tennessee Rivers. Buildings are surrounded by water and trees; their trunks are underwater
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Loading hogs onto the riverboat
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Pulleys; African Americans; Men; Women; Children; Swine; Corrals
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Several men are loading hogs from a chute or gangplank onto a riverboat. A pulley hoists the chute off of the bank. A corral is pictured in the background. A woman and two children, each wearing wide-brimmed hats, watch the scene from the side.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: It was common to send hogs off to slaughter by water rather than by land. If they were driven over land, they would lose weight and therefore some of their value.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A river landing scene
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Men; Waterfronts
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four men, three of them American American, load and unload goods at a river landing. The men are using a gangplank to access the riverboat. One man holds chickens and a package in his hand. A riverboat captain stands in the background.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Roustabouts" was the name given to the men who handled freight on the commercial steamboats that plied Southern rivers after the Civil War. Many worked at the river landings where the boats made stops.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mississippi River People
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Laborers; African Americans; Agricultural machinery & implements; Agricultural laborers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four Black laborers preparing to work. The three youngest, two boys and a girl, are barefoot. The youngest, a girl, is holding a hoe which is bigger than she is. Buildings are shown in the background.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Roustabouts" was the name given to the men who handled freight on the commercial steamboats that plied Southern rivers after the Civil War. Many worked at the river landings where the boats made stops.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cattle; Ox teams; Carts & wagons
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A team of yoked oxen pulling a wagon, possibly from a river landing. A man is standing nearby.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oxen led to water
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cattle; Carts & wagons; Ox teams; Women; African Americans; Bodies of water
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A team of yoked oxen in the foreground are led to the water's edge by their African-American handler. A group of women are seated on a wagon bed with a small building in the background.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oxen were a major work animal in 19th century Tennessee and supplied much of the power associated with loading and unloading cargo-laden steamboats.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Woman with child
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Toys; Women; Children
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: African-American woman with her hand on a young child's head. Both are cleanly dressed but barefoot. The young child is positioned behind her toy high chair, smiling into the camera. The woman seems to be squinting or frowning.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Women dipping water
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Bonnets; Clothing & dress; Children; Laundry
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Women wearing bonnets are lined up getting ready to take a cup of water from a bucket. They have their hands resting on the person's shoulders in front of them. The house in the background has a covered, attached structure sheltering a cistern. A child, sucking her thumb, is standing nearby watching the women.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
Tennessee State Library & Archives
